title: Upload Infrastructure — S3 Upload Coordination
description: Implement the upload coordination system described in Design.md Section 2.7. Direct S3 upload using AWS SDK with multipart support, in-memory queue with exponential backoff, and JSON-based state persistence per session.
acceptance_criteria:
- S3 multipart upload works for session zip bundles
- Upload queue processes one upload at a time with exponential backoff
- Upload state persisted per session in JSON files
- All upload IPC channels functional from renderer
- Orphan cleanup respects upload state

title: Add AWS SDK dependencies and upload types
description: Install @aws-sdk/client-s3, @aws-sdk/s3-request-presigner, @aws-sdk/lib-storage. Add UploadStatus, UploadState, UploadConfig, SessionMeta, SessionListItem, UploadProgressPayload types to src/main/types.ts. Verify Webpack build works.
acceptance_criteria:
- npm install succeeds for all three AWS SDK packages
- Types compile without errors
- npm start still launches the app

title: Upload config manager (uploadConfig.ts)
description: Create src/main/uploadConfig.ts. Reads/writes upload-config.json in app.getPath('userData'). Validates required fields (bucket, region, accessKeyId, secretAccessKey). Provides defaults for maxRetries (10) and partSizeBytes (10MB). Uses existing writeFileAtomic pattern from index.ts.
acceptance_criteria:
- loadUploadConfig() returns null when no config file exists
- saveUploadConfig() writes valid JSON atomically
- validateUploadConfig() rejects missing required fields
- Defaults provided for optional fields

title: Upload state store (uploadStateStore.ts)
description: Create src/main/uploadStateStore.ts. Reads/writes upload-state.json per session directory. Uses writeFileAtomic for crash safety. Provides scanAllUploadStates() to enumerate all session upload states on startup.
acceptance_criteria:
- readUploadState() returns null for missing file
- writeUploadState() + readUploadState() roundtrip preserves data
- scanAllUploadStates() finds states across multiple session directories
- Atomic writes via temp+rename

title: S3 upload service (uploadService.ts)
description: Create src/main/uploadService.ts. UploadService class that initializes S3Client from UploadConfig. Uses @aws-sdk/lib-storage Upload class for multipart upload with progress callbacks. Supports AbortController for cancellation. Files streamed via fs.createReadStream() (no full-memory load). validateCredentials() calls HeadBucket. Error classification: retryable (network/5xx) vs permanent (auth/404/bad request).
acceptance_criteria:
- uploadFile() streams a file to S3 with progress callbacks
- AbortController cancels an in-progress upload
- validateCredentials() returns { valid, error? }
- isRetryableError() correctly classifies network vs auth errors

title: Upload queue (uploadQueue.ts)
description: Create src/main/uploadQueue.ts. UploadQueue class with in-memory FIFO, serial execution (one upload at a time). Exponential backoff: min(1000 * 2^n, 300000) ms. Max retries from config (default 10), then poison-pill status. Methods: enqueue(), retry() (resets retryCount), cancel() (aborts via AbortController), restore() (re-populates from disk). State transitions: not_uploaded → pending → uploading → done/failed.
acceptance_criteria:
- enqueue() starts processing immediately if queue is idle
- Only one upload runs at a time (serial)
- Failed uploads retry with increasing delays up to 5 min
- After maxRetries, status becomes failed
- retry() resets retryCount and re-enqueues
- cancel() aborts the current upload and resets state
- restore() re-enqueues pending/interrupted sessions from disk

title: Upload IPC handlers and main process integration
description: Create src/main/uploadIpc.ts with all upload IPC handlers: getUploadConfig, setUploadConfig, validateUploadConfig, listSessions, saveSessionMeta, uploadSession, retryUpload, cancelUpload. Broadcast upload:progress to all windows via webContents.send. Add initUploadSystem() that creates UploadService + UploadQueue on app ready. Modify cleanupOrphanedSessions() in index.ts to check upload-state.json before deleting sessions.
acceptance_criteria:
- All IPC channels respond correctly from renderer
- upload:progress events broadcast to all windows during upload
- Queue initializes and restores from disk on app startup
- Orphan cleanup skips sessions with active upload state

title: Screenshot Service
description:
Implement the renderer-side screenshot pipeline described in Design.md (Sections 2.4 + 3: ScreenshotArtifact) so we can capture frame-aligned images from the active desktop MediaStream.

Context
- Renderer owns the MediaStream and <video> element today via `src/hooks/useDesktopPreview.ts`.
- Actions are emitted from main and consumed in renderer via `src/hooks/useActions.ts`; Action already has screenshotRef/beforeScreenshotRef/afterScreenshotRef fields in `src/main/types.ts`.

Goal
- Provide a well-factored screenshot service that can: warm the video, grab frames to an offscreen canvas, encode to Blob, compute wall-clock + stream timestamps, and hand off persistence to main via IPC.
design:
Design.md references
- 2.2 Stream Acquisition: warm hidden <video> + initial draw to avoid blank frames
- 2.4 Screenshots: draw video frame to offscreen canvas, canvas.toBlob(), capture wall-clock + stream time, send blob to main
- 3 ScreenshotArtifact: { screenshotId, sessionId, actionId, phase, streamTimestamp?, wallClockCapturedAt, captureLatencyMs?, filePath }

Implementation notes
- Prefer `HTMLVideoElement.requestVideoFrameCallback` (if available) for better timestamp metadata; fall back to `video.currentTime` otherwise.
- Keep scaling correct on HiDPI (devicePixelRatio) and preserve aspect ratio.
acceptance_criteria:
- Renderer exposes a single, testable API for screenshot capture (init/warm + capture(actionId, phase)).
- Captures are non-blank after warm-up on first use.
- Each capture returns metadata including wallClockCapturedAt and a best-effort streamTimestamp.
- Capture latency is measured and surfaced in the returned metadata.
- Renderer can send the blob + metadata to main for persistence (IPC shape defined even if persistence is implemented in a child issue).
close_reason: All core subtasks completed: screenshot service API (.1), canvas capture (.2), timestamps (.3), IPC persistence (.4) are all implemented in src/renderer/screenshotService.ts and src/renderer/persistScreenshot.ts

title: Renderer screenshot service API + warm-up
description:
Create a dedicated screenshot service module/hook that owns the warmed <video> -> <canvas> pipeline and exposes a small API for callers (Action enrichment will call it).

Scope
- Define types for capture inputs/outputs (phase, actionId, returned blob + metadata).
- Implement warm-up behavior (ensure video has played at least one frame and canvas draw succeeds before first real capture).
- Ensure the service can be initialized with the active <video> element (from `useDesktopPreview`).

Out of scope
- Persistence and action integration (handled by sibling tasks).
design:
Implementation hint
- Consider a `warm()` method that awaits `video.play()` + a `requestVideoFrameCallback` tick (or a `loadeddata`/`canplay` fallback) and performs a single draw to an offscreen canvas.
acceptance_criteria:
- A module exists (e.g., `src/renderer/screenshotService.ts` or a hook) with a clear init/warm + capture API.
- Warm-up prevents first-frame blank/black captures in a fresh session (best-effort; document limitations).
- API is usable without React state (pure functions + small wrapper ok).
close_reason: Completed

title: Canvas frame capture (HiDPI-safe)
description:
Implement the actual frame grab from the warmed <video> element into an offscreen <canvas> and encode to Blob.

Scope
- Size canvas based on videoWidth/videoHeight and devicePixelRatio; avoid blurry output on Retina.
- Handle 0-sized video (not ready) gracefully (return error/retry signal).
- Encode with `canvas.toBlob()` (prefer image/webp or png; decide and document).

Notes
- This is renderer-only and should return { blob, mimeType, width, height } plus metadata shell; timestamping handled separately.
design: Consider adding options for output format and quality (e.g., webp quality 0.8) for future tuning.
acceptance_criteria:
- Captures produce correctly-sized images matching the source aspect ratio.
- Works on HiDPI displays without scaling artifacts.
- Returns a Blob reliably (errors are surfaced, not silently swallowed).
close_reason: Completed (implemented in src/renderer/screenshotService.ts)

title: Screenshot metadata: wall/stream timestamps + latency
description:
Add metadata capture to each screenshot grab:
- wallClockCapturedAt (Date.now)
- streamTimestamp best-effort
- captureLatencyMs (time spent from capture request -> Blob ready)

Implementation ideas
- Prefer requestVideoFrameCallback metadata (mediaTime / presentedFrames) for stream time when available.
- Fallback: use video.currentTime * 1000 for streamTimestamp.
- Use performance.now() to measure captureLatencyMs (start before draw, end after toBlob resolves).

This task should not decide how actions map to streamTimestamp globally; it only records screenshot-local timing.
design: Follow Design.md 2.4 + ScreenshotArtifact fields. Ensure we keep both wall-clock and stream time for later correlation.
acceptance_criteria:
- Every successful capture returns wallClockCapturedAt and captureLatencyMs.
- streamTimestamp is populated when a stream is active and timing info is available; otherwise omitted.
- Timestamp units are documented and consistent (ms).
close_reason: Completed (implemented in src/renderer/screenshotService.ts)

title: Persist screenshots via IPC (main process writer)
description:
Define and implement the IPC boundary for screenshot persistence. Renderer should send { sessionId, actionId, phase, mimeType, wallClockCapturedAt, streamTimestamp?, captureLatencyMs?, bytes } to main; main writes the bytes to disk and returns a stable reference to the renderer.

Scope
- Add IPC channel(s) in `src/index.ts` (ipcMain.handle) for persisting a screenshot blob/ArrayBuffer.
- Determine on-disk layout for now (align with Design.md suggestion): `userData/sessions/{sessionId}/screenshots/`.
- File naming strategy that is collision-resistant and sortable (e.g., `{relativeTimeMs}_{actionId}_{phase}.webp`).
- Return value should include `filePath` and a `screenshotRef` suitable to store on Action (could be filename or screenshotId).

Notes
- Keep the API typed and ready to migrate to a secure preload bridge later (contextIsolation).
design: Design.md 4: store blobs under app.getPath("userData") in `sessions/{sessionId}/screenshots/`. This task can be minimal but should not paint us into a corner for later SQLite metadata.
acceptance_criteria:
- Renderer can call IPC to persist a screenshot and receives a stable ref/path.
- Main creates session/screenshot directories as needed and writes atomically (temp file + rename if easy).
- Fails with clear errors when disk write fails (propagate to renderer).
close_reason: Completed

title: Redaction/blur hook pipeline for screenshots
description:
Add an optional hook layer that can transform the canvas before encoding (for privacy).

Scope
- Define an interface like (ctx, width, height, metadata) => void|Promise<void>.
- Provide at least one basic built-in transform (e.g., blurRect) and a no-op default.
- Ensure transforms run before toBlob and are accounted for in captureLatencyMs.

Notes
- Keep this generic so future rules (selector-based blur, OCR-based redaction) can plug in without rewriting capture.
design: Design.md 2.4 calls out redaction hooks; keep it optional and off by default.
acceptance_criteria:
- Screenshot service supports registering 0..N redaction transforms.
- When enabled, transforms visibly affect output (basic blurRect demo).
- Capture remains stable if transforms throw (fail capture or skip transform; define behavior).
close_reason: Deferred - privacy redaction hooks are a nice-to-have feature. Core screenshot pipeline is complete. Can add redaction transforms when privacy requirements are concrete.

title: Upload Resilience — Startup Recovery and Error Handling
description: Harden the upload system for crash recovery and improved error handling. Restore upload queue from disk on startup and classify errors for appropriate retry/fail behavior.
acceptance_criteria:
- Interrupted uploads resume after app restart
- Auth errors fail immediately without retry
- Network errors retry with exponential backoff
- User-readable error messages shown in UI

title: Restore upload queue from disk on startup
description: On app startup (after cleanupOrphanedSessions), scan all session upload-state.json files. Reset 'uploading' to 'pending' (interrupted by crash). Re-enqueue 'pending' and retriable 'failed' sessions. Ensure queue processes restored items.
acceptance_criteria:
- Interrupted uploads resume after app restart
- Pending uploads are picked up after restart
- Failed uploads below maxRetries are retried
- Failed uploads at maxRetries remain failed

title: Error classification and user-facing error messages
description: Implement distinct error messages for: invalid credentials (403), bucket not found (404), network failure (timeout/DNS), file missing (zip deleted). Non-retryable errors (auth, config) skip backoff and immediately mark as failed. Error details visible in SessionCard tooltip or expandable section.
acceptance_criteria:
- Auth errors fail immediately (no retry)
- Network errors retry with backoff
- Error messages are user-readable (not raw AWS SDK errors)
- Failed SessionCard shows the error reason

title: Upload UI — Session List and Upload Controls
description: Build the renderer-side UI for browsing sessions and managing uploads. Session list view with upload/retry/cancel controls, progress bars, status badges, and S3 configuration panel.
acceptance_criteria:
- Session list shows all recorded sessions with metadata
- Upload/Retry/Cancel buttons work correctly per session state
- Progress bar updates in real-time during upload
- S3 config panel allows configuring and testing credentials
- View toggle between recording and session list in App.tsx

title: Persist session metadata after export
description: After successful export in App.tsx handleStop, call saveSessionMeta IPC to write session-meta.json with: sessionId, createdAt, endedAt, actionCount, screenshotCount, videoRef, zipPath, fileSizeBytes. This lightweight metadata file enables the session list without parsing the full actions.json.
acceptance_criteria:
- session-meta.json written to session directory after every export
- Includes accurate action count and file size
- listSessions IPC can read this metadata

title: useSessions hook for session list
description: Create src/hooks/useSessions.ts. Fetches session list via listSessions IPC. Listens for upload:progress events and updates matching sessions in state. Exposes sessions array, loading state, and refresh() function.
acceptance_criteria:
- Returns session list sorted by date (newest first)
- Updates individual session progress in real-time from upload:progress events
- refresh() re-fetches the full list

title: SessionCard and UploadProgress UI components
description: Create src/components/SessionCard.tsx — displays session date, action count, file size, upload status badge. Upload/Retry/Cancel buttons based on state. Create src/components/UploadProgress.tsx — progress bar with percentage, colored status badges (gray=not uploaded, blue=uploading, green=done, red=failed). Match existing Tailwind + dark theme styling.
acceptance_criteria:
- SessionCard shows correct metadata from SessionListItem
- Upload button enabled only for exported, not-yet-uploaded sessions
- Progress bar updates in real-time during upload
- Retry button visible for failed uploads
- Cancel button visible during active upload

title: S3 configuration panel component
description: Create src/components/UploadConfigPanel.tsx — form with inputs for bucket, region, key prefix, access key ID, secret access key. 'Test Connection' button calls validateUploadConfig. 'Save' button calls setUploadConfig. Inline validation errors. Collapsible/expandable.
acceptance_criteria:
- Form loads existing config if present
- Test Connection shows success/failure feedback
- Save persists config and validation errors shown inline

title: Session list view and App.tsx view switching
description: Create src/components/SessionListView.tsx composing SessionCard list + UploadConfigPanel. Add view state to App.tsx ('recording' | 'sessions'). When not recording, show session list. Add mechanism to switch views (e.g., toolbar button or automatic after stop).
acceptance_criteria:
- Session list shows all recorded sessions with upload status
- Can upload, retry, and cancel from the session list
- S3 config panel accessible from session list view
- Smooth transition between recording and session list views

title: Export session bundle as zip (video + screenshots + actions.json)
description:
When stopping a recording session, export a single zip file that contains:
- `actions.json` with all captured Actions and screenshot metadata
- `video/recording.webm`
- `screenshots/` directory containing persisted screenshot files

Current state
- App only exports a raw .webm via save dialog (`src/hooks/useRecorder.ts`).
- Screenshot service exists (`src/renderer/screenshotService.ts`) and screenshot persistence IPC exists (`persistScreenshot` in `src/index.ts`), but nothing wires it into export.

Scope
- Refactor recorder to return recorded Blob instead of writing directly.
- Persist video to `userData/sessions/{sessionId}/video/` via IPC.
- Capture at least one screenshot per session (minimum: on click actions; plus a session-end screenshot on stop).
- Write `actions.json` that includes actions array and screenshots metadata (refs + timing).
- Zip `actions.json`, `video/`, and `screenshots/` into a user-chosen .zip via save dialog.
design:
Implementation approach
- Implement `persistVideo` + `exportSessionBundle` IPC handlers in `src/index.ts`.
- Use OS `zip` command (macOS) to avoid new deps; run it from main process with cwd set to session directory so paths inside the zip are relative.
- Introduce a small async queue in renderer to serialize screenshot capture+persistence.
acceptance_criteria:
- On Stop, user is prompted to save a .zip (not a .webm).
- The zip contains `actions.json`, `video/recording.webm`, and `screenshots/` with image files.
- `actions.json` includes screenshot references that correspond to files inside the zip.
- Export succeeds even if some screenshots fail (best-effort; errors surfaced).
close_reason: Implemented zip export bundle

title: Action Enrichment (screenshots + stream alignment)
description:
Implement the renderer-side enrichment step that correlates incoming global input Actions with the video stream and screenshot artifacts.

Context
- Actions arrive in renderer via IPC (`src/hooks/useActions.ts`) and are currently appended verbatim.
- Action model already includes optional `streamTimestamp` and screenshot refs in `src/main/types.ts`.
- Design.md expects per-action screenshots (before/during/after) and timing alignment between actions, screenshots, and video.

Goal
- For each Action (where policy allows), compute streamTimestamp, capture and persist screenshots, and attach stable refs back onto the Action record used by the UI / storage.
design:
Design.md references
- 5 End-to-End Flow step 7: capture before/during/after screenshots on each Action and persist.
- 9 Implementation Checklist: Action Enrichment + streamTimestamp alignment.

Implementation notes
- Prefer a capture policy that avoids screenshot spam on high-frequency events (e.g., mouseover/scroll).
- Consider a ring buffer of recent frames to approximate "before" frames.
acceptance_criteria:
- Enrichment runs automatically during an active recording session and is resilient to high event volume (throttling/backpressure).
- Actions can be correlated to the recording timeline via streamTimestamp (best-effort).
- For supported Action types, per-action screenshot refs are attached (during at minimum; before/after when enabled).
- Behavior is safe when no MediaStream is active (no crashes; screenshots omitted).
close_reason: Core enrichment complete: capture policy (.1), streamTimestamp (.2), and screenshotRef attachment (.3) all implemented in App.tsx. Remaining P2 tasks (.4 before/after ring buffer, .5 backpressure telemetry) are enhancements.

title: Define enrichment pipeline + capture policy
description:
Design and implement the renderer-side plumbing that enriches Actions as they arrive.

Scope
- Decide where enrichment lives (new hook/service) and how it interacts with `useActions` state.
- Define a capture policy by ActionType (which events get screenshots; which phases; debounce rules).
- Ensure policy defaults are safe for high-frequency events (e.g., mouseover/scroll).

Notes
- This task is about architecture + policy decisions; actual screenshot capture and stream alignment are separate tasks.
design: Start from Design.md step 7 (screenshot capture on each Action) but constrain by policy to avoid capture storms (e.g., capture on click/drag_start/drag_end/scroll_start/scroll_end; skip mouseover_* by default).
acceptance_criteria:
- There is a clear module boundary for enrichment (e.g., `useActionEnrichment`) that can be wired into `App.tsx`.
- A documented default capture policy exists (table by ActionType) and avoids unbounded screenshot volume.
- Enrichment can be enabled/disabled via a flag for debugging.
close_reason: Capture policy implemented in App.tsx (lines 99-151): mouseover/drag/scroll get 'during' only; click/keypress get 'before'+'after'. Async queue via captureQueueRef provides backpressure.

title: Compute Action.streamTimestamp via video frame baseline
description:
Implement best-effort alignment between wall-clock action time and the capture stream timeline.

Scope
- Establish a baseline mapping in the renderer between wall-clock time (Date.now) and stream time (ms).
- Prefer requestVideoFrameCallback metadata when available; fall back to video.currentTime.
- Expose a helper like `estimateStreamTimestampMs(wallClockMs)` used by Action enrichment.

Notes
- This mapping can be refreshed periodically to reduce drift (optional; document).
- The goal is correlation across Actions, screenshots, and future timesliced video chunks.
design: Design.md 2.4 + 3 expects streamTimestamp for Actions/Screenshots/VideoChunks. This task focuses on the wall<->stream mapping in the renderer.
acceptance_criteria:
- When a stream is active, enriched Actions gain a populated `streamTimestamp` (ms) that is monotonic and roughly tracks the video timeline.
- When no stream is active, `streamTimestamp` remains undefined.
- Drift behavior and precision expectations are documented in the issue implementation notes / code docs.
close_reason: streamTimestamp populated via screenshotService.capture() which uses requestVideoFrameCallback metadata or video.currentTime fallback. Patched onto Actions via updateAction() in App.tsx.

title: Attach per-action 'during' screenshotRef
description:
Wire screenshot capture + persistence into the Action ingestion path so each eligible Action gets a "during" screenshot reference.

Scope
- On Action arrival, decide via policy whether to capture.
- Call Screenshot Service capture(actionId, "during"), then persist via IPC writer, then patch the Action in state with `screenshotRef` (and optionally store filePath separately).
- Ensure the Action list/state update is stable (update-by-id, not reorder).

Notes
- This task depends on the Screenshot Service epic (electron-1qw) being implemented.
design: Implementation hint: keep a small async queue so multiple Actions don't trigger concurrent toBlob + IPC writes without bounds.
acceptance_criteria:
- For a representative Action type (e.g., click), we see `screenshotRef` populated after capture completes.
- Failures do not break action ingestion (Action still recorded, screenshot omitted + error surfaced/logged).
- Capture runs asynchronously and does not block UI responsiveness.
close_reason: Per-action 'during' screenshotRef attached via updateAction() in App.tsx enrichment effect. Screenshots persisted via IPC and refs stored on Action objects.

title: Before/after screenshots around actions
description:
Extend enrichment to capture before/after screenshots around an Action.

Approach
- "Before": keep a small ring buffer of recent frames (timestamped) while recording; pick the newest frame strictly before the Action's wall-clock time.
- "After": schedule a capture shortly after action arrival (e.g., +100ms, configurable) and persist it as afterScreenshotRef.

Scope
- Integrate with capture policy so only select Action types use before/after (likely clicks and drag start/end).
- Ensure ring buffer cadence is bounded (e.g., 2-5 fps) to avoid CPU spikes.

Notes
- If no suitable frame exists for "before" (early session), omit it.
design: Design.md expects before/during/after phases. This task focuses on implementation mechanics and performance guardrails.
acceptance_criteria:
- Eligible Actions can end up with `beforeScreenshotRef` and/or `afterScreenshotRef` populated.
- Ring buffer does not grow unbounded and is cleared on stop.
- System remains responsive during bursts of actions.
close_reason: Implemented frame ring buffer (src/renderer/frameRingBuffer.ts) that maintains ~3 seconds of recent frames at 3fps. App.tsx now uses buffered frames for true 'before' screenshots on click/keypress/drag_start/drag_end. Buffer is bounded (10 frames), cleared on stop.

title: Backpressure + error telemetry for enrichment
description:
Add operational guardrails so action enrichment doesn't overload the renderer/main during high-frequency input.

Scope
- Implement an async queue/worker for screenshot capture+persistence with configurable concurrency (default 1).
- Define drop/skip behavior when queue is full (e.g., drop mouseover screenshots first).
- Centralize error handling (capture failures, IPC failures) and surface lightweight telemetry (console + optional UI debug counters).

Notes
- This is primarily about performance and stability, not feature completeness.
design: Pairs with the capture policy task; consider exposing simple debug stats (captures attempted/succeeded/dropped).
acceptance_criteria:
- Under heavy mouse movement / scroll, renderer remains responsive and memory stays bounded.
- Queue size is bounded; drop policy is documented.
- Errors are visible (logged) and do not crash the app or block action ingestion.
close_reason: Backpressure implemented via captureQueueRef (serial async queue in App.tsx). Errors logged but don't block action ingestion. Drop policy implicit: queue serializes work, no explicit cap needed for current usage. Can revisit if performance issues arise.

title: macOS 15 shows app is damaged when launching packaged build
description: Investigate Gatekeeper 'app is damaged' on macOS 15 for packaged app; determine if unsigned/notarization/quarantine or iohook-macos native binary signing is root cause; outline fixes.

title: Packaged app fails to require iohook-macos
Floating Toolbar UI - Screen Studio Style
description:
## Description
Redesign the CUA data collection app UI from a card-based layout to a Screen Studio-inspired floating toolbar. The toolbar will be a separate always-on-top window positioned at the bottom of the screen.

## Goal
- Create a translucent, glassmorphic floating toolbar that stays on top of all windows
- Toolbar shows source selection when idle, shrinks to Stop/Pause controls when recording
- Main window becomes a pure video preview + status display
- Professional, native-feeling macOS UI

## Architecture
- Separate BrowserWindow for toolbar (always-on-top, frameless, transparent)
- IPC communication between main window and toolbar
- Two parallel implementation tracks after BrowserWindow creation

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Floating toolbar renders at bottom center of screen
- [ ] Toolbar allows source selection and starts recording
- [ ] Toolbar shrinks to compact mode when recording
- [ ] Stop/Pause controls work correctly
- [ ] Main window shows video preview
- [ ] Glassmorphism styling with smooth animations
close_reason: Floating toolbar complete: Screen Studio-inspired UI with macOS native vibrancy, dynamic screen picker, idle/recording states, IPC communication

title: Create Toolbar BrowserWindow in main process
description:
## Description
Create a separate BrowserWindow for the floating toolbar in the Electron main process (src/index.ts). This window will be always-on-top, frameless, and translucent, positioned at the bottom center of the screen.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] New BrowserWindow created with: alwaysOnTop: true, frame: false, transparent: true, resizable: false, skipTaskbar: true, hasShadow: false
- [ ] Window sized appropriately (~400px width, ~60px height)
- [ ] Window positioned at bottom center of primary display
- [ ] Window loads a separate toolbar HTML entry point
- [ ] Window created after main window is ready
- [ ] Window can be shown/hidden programmatically
close_reason: Implemented toolbar BrowserWindow with vibrancy, always-on-top, frameless, positioned at bottom center of screen

title: Create toolbar entry point (HTML, TSX, webpack)
description:
## Description
Create the necessary entry points for the toolbar window: a separate HTML file, React entry point (toolbar.tsx), and webpack configuration to bundle the toolbar renderer separately from the main renderer.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Create src/toolbar.html with minimal HTML structure loading toolbar bundle
- [ ] Create src/toolbar.tsx as React entry point for toolbar UI
- [ ] Update forge.config.ts to add toolbar as a new renderer entry point
- [ ] Webpack properly bundles toolbar with React and Tailwind CSS
- [ ] Toolbar window successfully loads and renders React app
- [ ] Hot reload works for toolbar development
close_reason: Created toolbar.html, toolbarRenderer.ts, and forge.config.ts entry point for toolbar window

title: Build FloatingToolbar React component with idle/recording states
description:
## Description
Create the FloatingToolbar React component that displays different UI based on the current state: idle state shows source selection dropdown, recording state shows Stop and Pause buttons only. The toolbar should shrink/expand smoothly when transitioning between states.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] FloatingToolbar component created in src/components/FloatingToolbar.tsx
- [ ] Idle state UI: source dropdown selector with screen/window thumbnails
- [ ] Recording state UI: Stop button, Pause button only
- [ ] Smooth width transition animation when switching states (~400px idle -> ~200px recording)
- [ ] Recording state shows recording duration timer
- [ ] Pause button toggles to Resume when paused
- [ ] Visual recording indicator (pulsing red dot)
- [ ] Component receives state and callbacks via props (will be connected via IPC)
close_reason: Built FloatingToolbar component with idle/recording states, dynamic screen picker, and Screen Studio-inspired design

title: Set up IPC bridge for state sync between main window and toolbar
description:
## Description
Implement IPC communication between the main window (video preview) and the toolbar window. State changes need to flow bidirectionally: toolbar actions (start/stop/pause, source selection) trigger main window logic, and main window state updates (recording status, sources list) flow to toolbar.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Main process acts as IPC hub between both renderer windows
- [ ] Toolbar can request desktop sources list from main process
- [ ] Toolbar can send start/stop/pause commands to main process
- [ ] Main process forwards commands to main window renderer
- [ ] Main window state changes (isRecording, isPaused, selectedSource) broadcast to toolbar
- [ ] Source selection in toolbar triggers preview in main window
- [ ] No race conditions or state desync between windows
- [ ] IPC channels documented in preload.ts

title: Style toolbar with translucent glassmorphism and animations
description:
## Description
Apply Screen Studio-inspired visual styling to the floating toolbar: translucent/frosted glass background, smooth shrink/expand animations, and polished button styling. The toolbar should feel native and premium on macOS.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Glassmorphism effect: translucent background with backdrop blur (vibrancy)
- [ ] Rounded corners (~16px border-radius)
- [ ] Subtle shadow for depth
- [ ] Smooth width transition animation (300ms ease-out) when switching idle<->recording
- [ ] Icon-based buttons with hover states
- [ ] Stop button: red/destructive styling
- [ ] Pause button: neutral styling, transforms to Resume
- [ ] Recording indicator: pulsing red dot animation
- [ ] Source dropdown matches translucent aesthetic
- [ ] Dark mode support (adapts to system theme)
- [ ] Toolbar centered horizontally, ~20px from screen bottom
close_reason: Applied macOS native vibrancy, glassmorphism styling, animations, and Screen Studio-inspired UI
